titleStmt.title: Cylindrically symmetric, static strings with a cosmological constant in Brans-Dicke theory

analytic.title: Cylindrically symmetric, static strings with a cosmological constant in Brans-Dicke theory

abstract.p: The static, cylindrically symmetric vacuum solutions with a cosmological constant in the framework of the Brans-Dicke theory are investigated. Some of these solutions admitting Lorentz boost invariance along the symmetry axis correspond to local, straight cosmic strings with a cosmological constant. Some physical properties of such solutions are studied. These strings apply attractive or repulsive forces on the test particles. A smooth matching is also performed with a recently introduced interior thick string solution with a cosmological constant.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: The Brans-Dicke (BD) theory [1] is a natural generalization of the Einstein's general relativity (GR) where the gravitational coupling constant is replaced by a scalar field. The inclusion of scalar fields into GR is suggested by different theories, for example, as a dilaton field which naturally arises in low energy limit of string theories or in the Kaluza-Klein theories. This theory has some desirable properties [2] such as it obeys the weak equivalence principle and it is also compatible with the solar system experiments for large values of its parameter. This theory has been applied to several issues ranging from inflation schemes in cosmology to quantum gravity [3].

In this paper, we will obtain static cylindrically symmetric vacuum solutions in the presence of a cosmological constant in the framework of the Brans-Dicke scalar tensor theory. These solutions can describe exterior regions of static cylindrically symmetric sources. An important subclass of the solutions we present are the solutions corresponding to static, straight, local cosmic strings. Cosmic strings are linear topological defects which may have been produced in the early universe during the phase transitions in the general unified theories [4, 5]. Due to their important implications on cosmology and astrophysics, they have attracted a lot of interest during the last decades, especially because of the possibility that they can generate density fluctuations in the early universe which can give rise to the formation of galaxies, etc. Although recent observations ruled out this possibility in favor of inflation and they cannot be the primary source for such fluctuations, they can still contribute up to 10% [6, 7], which can be detectable in the future observations. The interest on cosmic strings was renewed [8] due to several reasons, such as their relations with fundamental strings in string theory [9]-[11] or their possible observational consequences [12]-[14] due to their gravitational lensing effects. In the framework of scalar-tensor theories, cosmic strings are investigated in detail [15]-[26]. Strings with a cosmological constant in GR theory is presented by Linet [27] and Tian [28]. Note that, the solutions with a cosmological constant for a diagonal metric which depends only on one variable were studied for GR [29] and BD [30] theories before. The solutions we will discuss, in certain limits, reduce to exterior cosmic strings with [27, 28] or without [4] cosmological constant in GR, or cosmic strings in BD theory [16]-[19]. Moreover, some particular solutions we will discuss do not have a GR analogue. Since there are evidences that we can have a nonzero cosmological constant in the present universe [31], and different theories [3] suggest that we can have a scalar field nonminimally coupled to gravity, it might be interesting to find a solution describing cosmic strings in the presence of cosmological constant in a scalar tensor theory of gravitation. The paper is organized as follows. In Sec. II and III, we will introduce the field equations for a general static cylindrically symmetric ansatz and their different general solutions. Then, in Sec. IV, we will select the solutions corresponding to static, straight cosmic strings among these solutions. Some of the physical properties of such solutions will be discussed in Sec. V and VI. In Sec. VII, by matching a recently introduced regular interior thick string solution [34] smoothly, we will show that these exterior string solutions can be generated by cosmic strings. Then, we finish with a brief discussion.

Note that a conformal transformation is needed since those solutions are presented in the conformal or Einstein frame, which is related with the BD frame by a conformal transformation. For the GR limit, these conditions give us two different solutions. The first one is the famous cosmic string solution of Vilenkin (a 0 , a 2 , a 3 ) = (0, 0, 1) and the second one is related with supermassive or global strings (a 0 , a 2 , a 3 ) = (2/3, 2/3, −1/3).

div.head: V. SINGULARITY BEHAVIOUR
div.p: Let us first consider the general solution (29-30). First of all, GR strings do not have curvature singularity on the axis [27], whereas BD strings have, due to the interaction of BD scalar. Secondly, unlike Λ < 0 case, GR strings with Λ > 0 are singular at r = r g = π/ √ 3Λ. For the BD theory we have the similar case and for α > 0 the solutions are singular at r = r b = π/ √ α where α is given in (10). Actually, for BD case the solutions depend on the sign of α rather than Λ. However, since the cases that they have different signs (−3/2 < ω < −4/3) are excluded, otherwise the metric functions become imaginary for this interval, we cannot have solutions which α and Λ have different signs. Thus, for GR and BD theories, the solutions with Λ > 0 are singular at r = r b . Due to singularity at r = r b either the solutions with Λ > 0 must be excluded or following Tian [28], they can describe a string in a closed universe whose topology is R 2 × S 2 . This can be achieved by transforming the radial coordinate as r = χ + χ 0 where χ 0 = r b = π/ √ α and the coordinate χ have the range χ 0 ≤ χ ≤ π/ √ α. Another important difference is the special solution (III B 1) which has no GR analogue for Λ = 0. This solution is also singular on the axis in general and it is not singular for finite r unless r → ∞. We can avoid the singularity at the radial infinity by applying the prescription given in the previous paragraph. For the following choice of parameters, we can have a metric similar to cosmic string metric in GR for b 4 = b 0 = b 1 = 0, b 3 = 1:
This solution is not singular at r = 0, but it is singular at r → ∞. Its Ricci scalar is R = −2(7Λ + 6Λ 2 r 2 ) and the other curvature scalars have the same behavior.

When r is negative (positive) the string applies attractive (repulsive) force whereas when it vanishes it applies no force on a test particle initially at rest. We see that the behaviour of the force depends on the terms inside the parenthesis: the constant c 0 and the term κ(r) = (ω + 1)/(3ω + 4) cosh ( |α|r). (47)

When c 0 positive, if κ(r) is also positive (ω > −1 or ω < −4/3) string applies attractive force everywhere, whereas if κ(r) is negative (ω ∈ (−1, −4/3)) , the force becomes repulsive whenever |κ| > c 0 . For negative c 0 the situation is reverse and if κ(r) is also negative the force is repulsive everywhere, whereas for positive κ the force becomes attractive for larger r when |c 0 | < κ.

div.head: VII. INTERIOR SOLUTIONS
div.p: The interior region of a static straight local cosmic string can be modelled by an anisotropic fluid having the energy momentum tensor of the form: T µ ν = diag(−ρ, p r , p z , p ϕ ), (48)

Here ρ is the energy density and p r , p z , and p ϕ are the principal pressures. In GR theory with no cosmological constant, Λ = 0, local cosmic strings can be characterized by a phenomenological equation of state due to Vilenkin [33]

However, in the presence of a cosmological constant in GR theory, we have to take into account other pressures (p r , p φ ) as nonvanishing [28], otherwise we do not have any solution apart from vacuum one. This is also the case for the Brans-Dicke theory without Λ , since Sen et. al. showed [20] that the Vilenkin's ansatz ρ = −p z , with other pressures are vanishing is inconsistent. This inconsistency can be removed for different cases such as for nonstatic strings [22], or for a more general scalar tensor theory [23]. Furthermore, in a recent paper [34], it has been shown that, in the presence of a cosmological constant, this ansatz for interior region is indeed consistent. Since c 0 and c 5 in (31) depends on c 4 and ω (30), we have six equations for nine unknowns C 0 , C 3 , φ 0 , C, c 4 , α, β, r 0− , r 0+ . Thus, from the junction conditions, the exterior metric and scalar field parameters can be determined in terms of the interior metric and scalar field parameters r 0− , β, C. Hence, these junction conditions are fulfilled. This yields a configuration with a thick string on the axis with vacuum exterior with Λ in BD theory.

div.head: VIII. DISCUSSION
div.p: In this paper cylindrically symmetric static solutions of the Brans-Dicke field equations in the presence of a cosmological constant are investigated. Among these, the solutions admitting boost invariance along the symmetry (z) axis can represent the exterior fields of cosmic strings with Λ. Some physical properties of these solutions such as their singularity behaviour and motion of test particles are discussed. Then, we have shown that it is possible to match these exterior solutions with an regular interior string solution with Λ [34], having a phenomenological equation of state ρ = −p z , smoothly.

In BD theory with a cosmological constant, as in GR theory with Λ, local strings have nonvanishing gravitational potential and affects the motion of test particles. Our investigations in Sec. VI show that, these strings can apply either an attractive or repulsive force on a test particle initially at rest, depending of the parameters c 0 , |Λ|, ω and the radial distance from the string. The junction condition (60) yields that we have c 0 = −κ(r 0+ ) where κ(r) is given in Eq. (47) and r 0+ is the thickness of the string according to exterior metric (31). Hence, c 0 is negative for all values of ω except for ω ∈ (−4/3, −1) and the gravitational behaviour of the string is directly related to its thickness and its tension. Strings with negative cosmological constant are well behaving everywhere, they are only singular at the origin, but since there is an interior solution occupying the axis and smoothly matching to the exterior, this is not a problem.

However, for the strings with positive cosmological constant, there is a singularity from the finite distance from the axis. Hence, a string with a positive cosmological constant cannot be physically acceptable unless the space-time has a closed topology.
